name: deep well drilling, for deep geothermal power | deep well, drilled, for geothermal power | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/13819/documentation

This activity represents the exchanges associated with 1 meter of drilling of a borehole for deep geothermal power generation. The inventory reflects the conditions for a well with a depth of 5000m (exchanges do not scale linealry with depth). Geothermal drilling profits from the experience gained in onshore oil and natural gas drilling. This data set is based on a data set comprised in the book 'Energy from the earth'. (see field 'published source' for more details). The life cycle inventories established for this dataset on geothermal power is based on the literature information provided in the book (see published source). Data are representative for geologic conditions in Switzerland and as first approximation used for this activity. Uncertainties are adjusted accordingly.  If this activity is used for drilling at remote locations, diesel should be used as energy source for drilling instead of electricity.

This is an onshore (rotatory drilling service station) service starting with the reciept of chemicals, reinforcing materials and energy for the drilling. The energy source is electricity from the grid. Diesel is only used as a stand by and for activities on or related to the drill site.  

Deep onshore borehole ready for use. Borehole casing (steel, cement) remains in the ground after end of life of the geothermal plant (no waste treatment).
category: B:Mining and quarrying/09:Mining support service activities/099:Support activities for other mining and quarrying/0990:Support activities for other mining and quarrying

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Represents installation of a deep geothermal power plant in Switzerland, extrapolated to this geography. The inventory reflects the conditions for a 5000 m well.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Onshore drilling with a rig capacity of 6.75 MWel. The diameter of the borehole at the top is 10 inches.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Extrapolated from a dataset modelled for CH conditions.

publication.name: S Hirchberg, S Wiemer, P Burgherr2015

flow.name: deep well, drilled, for geothermal power
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/09:Mining support service activities/099:Support activities for other mining and quarrying/0990:Support activities for other mining and quarrying

exchanges.description: Calculated value.  This item belongs to the casing activity during the drilling process. Steel use for the casing calculated for a given well design (length of well sections, borehole and pipe diameters and well depth).

flow.category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/241:Manufacture of basic iron and steel/2410:Manufacture of basic iron and steel

exchanges.description:
Assumption. A drill site area of 18’000m2 is assumed, including the actual
drilling rig area, storage area, etc.

This item belongs to the Infrastructure category of the LCI.

Assumption. Amounts for the drilling fluid components are rough estimations. They further represent an average mix over the whole drilling time and not specific drilling fluid compositions for the different stages during the drilling process.
Source: Kaiser, M., and Fäs, M. (2004). Umweltverträglichkeitsbericht (Hauptuntersuchung) Deep Heat Mining, Basel, Switzerland. Gruner AG Ingenieure und Planer, Geohermal Explorers Ltd./ Sonderegger, M. (2013). Personal Communication with M. Sonderegger, Sankt Galler Stadtwerke, Switzerland.
This item belongs to the drilling fluid category of the LCI.

flow.name: sodium chloride, powder
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/08:Other mining and quarrying/089:Mining and quarrying n.e.c./0893:Extraction of salt

defaultProvider.name: market for sodium chloride, powder | sodium chloride, powder | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: B:Mining and quarrying/08:Other mining and quarrying/089:Mining and quarrying n.e.c./0893:Extraction of salt

exchanges.description:
Assumption. The amount for the use of water per m in the drilling fluid is a rather rough estimation.
This item belongs to the Drilling fluid category of the LCI.

Assumption. It is assumed that the actual drilling time amounts to 6 months for 5000 m, and that the preparation and closing time of the drill site amounts to 4 months.
This item belongs to the Infrastructure category of the LCI.

Calculated value. This item belongs to the casing activity during the drilling process. Cement use for the casing calculated for a given well design (length of well sections, borehole and pipe diameters and well depth). A loss factor of 1.5 is assumed.
Geothermal cements should tie well casing to the rock formation, be impermeable, hydraulically isolate the well from geological strata other than those related to production and injection, and resist attack b substances present in geothermal reservoirs. It is normally a cement of low density, mainly Portland cement class G with a density of around 1800 kg/m3. 
No dataset for class G cement exists in ecoinvent, so that this
dataset is taken as a proxy. No data for special additives were
available.

exchanges.description:
Assumption. It is assumed that the total volume of water used for the drilling fluid is treated (not considering any losses). An additional amount of meteoric water is estimated. The wastewater from the drilling place is partly first stored at place and used for laboratory testing. All wastewater goes to the public wastewater treatment plant. 
COD is estimated to be 3kg, DOC 0.3kg, Potassium ions in the water 0.9kg, sodium ions in the water 6kg. These values could not be modelled in this inventory.

flow.category: E:Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities/37:Sewerage/370:Sewerage/3700:Sewerage

defaultProvider.category: E:Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities/37:Sewerage/370:Sewerage/3700:Sewerage

exchanges.description:
Calculated value/estimation. Electricity use for the drilling process (including tripping time) calculated as a function of well depth, well design, well volume and installed rig capacity necessary for the well and geological conditions.

Energy use for the drilling process does not show a linear behaviour. This exchange value is therefore only correct for the specific conditions as specified in the report 'Energy from the Earth' (see source field).

exchanges.description:
Assumption. Rather pessimistic assumption of diesel use for
- different applications at the drilling site (i.e. staplers), based on St. Gallen
- backup in case of electrical power outage, based on Basel. 
Source: Haering, M. (2003). Deep Heat Mining Basel. Voruntersuchung und Pflichtenheft für die Umweltverträglichkeits-Prüfung. : Geothermal Explorers Ltd., Basel, Schweiz./ Sonderegger, M. (2013). Personal Communication with M. Sonderegger, Sankt Galler Stadtwerke,
Switzerland.
